title: Netilat Yadayim after partial immersion
vignette: A person immerses only his hands in spring water before eating bread. Is a separate cup pouring still required?

options.text: Yes, wash again from a vessel.
The immersion suffices without pouring.

title: Hands touch impure scroll
vignette: While studying, one’s hands brush against a dusty but sacred scroll. Must he rewash before eating?

options.text: Yes, contact with holy books defiles hands.
No, casual contact does not require rewashing.

title: Washing with minimal water
vignette: Only a small amount of water remains in the cup, barely enough for both hands.

options.text: Use the little water and proceed.
Seek more water even if it delays the meal.

title: Two people sharing one cup
vignette: Travelers have a single cup for washing hands before eating. Should each pour separately or may they share the water?

options.text: Pour once and pass the cup quickly.
Each should refill and pour individually.

title: Uncertain water source
vignette: A pitcher of water might have been used already for washing. Is it valid for a new washing?

options.text: Yes, reuse it to avoid waste.
Better to refill from a known source.

title: Using fruit juice
vignette: Only wine is available for washing before bread.

options.text: It counts as washing in a pinch.
Liquids other than water are invalid.

title: Washing in the dark
vignette: Guests eat outdoors at night with no lamp. They cannot see if water covers every part of the hand.

options.text: Proceed trusting the washing was thorough.
Rewash inside where they can see clearly.

title: Drying on a towel previously used
vignette: The only towel was used earlier by someone whose hands were unwashed.

options.text: Use it anyway; drying doesn't transfer impurity.
Let hands air-dry to stay pure.

title: Spilled water on the floor
vignette: After washing, the leftover water splashes onto a clean floor. Is it now impure and must be wiped up?

options.text: Yes, wipe it to avoid impurity spread.
No concern; let it evaporate.

title: Washing one hand at a time
vignette: A worker’s left hand is bandaged. Can he wash the right hand alone before eating?

options.text: Yes, wash the healthy hand and eat carefully.
Both hands must be washed together or not at all.

title: Children’s messy hands
vignette: Small children want to join the meal but continually touch dirt after washing.

options.text: Allow them to eat without rewashing each time.
Make them rewash whenever they touch dirt.

title: Disputed custom
vignette: In one community people wash three times on each hand; travelers wash only twice.

options.text: Follow the local stringency of three times.
Keep personal custom of two times.

title: Speaking between washing and blessing
vignette: Someone answers a brief greeting after washing but before reciting the blessing on bread.

options.text: Repeat the washing to avoid interruption.
Continue to the blessing without rewashing.

title: Communal washing station
vignette: At a large event, several spigots provide water simultaneously. Is washing valid if each person turns on their own tap?

options.text: Yes, each may use a spigot directly.
No, water must be poured from a vessel.

title: Doubt whether washing occurred
vignette: After preparing food, one cannot recall if he washed his hands. No one saw him do so.

options.text: Assume he did not wash and do it now.
Presume he washed and proceed to eat.
